content.body: sideshowbarker: now that MDN seems to do more things with its issue tracker, should we add something to the PR template asking us to file an issue on MDN for changes that might require doc updates?
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: now that MDN seems to do more things with its issue tracker, should we add something to the PR template asking us to file an issue on MDN for changes that might require doc updates?

content.body: Interesting how a force push of main shows up in all PRs, but not https://github.com/whatwg/html/commits
Domenic: yeah, good idea — that would be great
content.formatted_body: Domenic: yeah, good idea — that would be great

content.body:
speaking of MDN, we unfortunately still have many code examples there with iframes that call `alert()` — which outside of just being quaint and bad, no longer works in Chrome:
> A different origin subframe tried to create a JavaScript dialog. This is no longer allowed and was blocked. See https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5148698084376576 for more details.
content.formatted_body:
speaking of MDN, we unfortunately still have many code examples there with iframes that call alert() — which outside of just being quaint and bad, no longer works in Chrome:

A different origin subframe tried to create a JavaScript dialog. This is no longer allowed and was blocked. See https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5148698084376576 for more details.

content.formatted_body: Although I guess I could ping emilio directly ^

content.body:
Hello
Section 4.2.6 of the WhatWG HTML spec specifies what immediately happens when a style element is encountered. It references CSSWG, which says that the stylesheet gets added to the "document or shadow root CSS style sheets".
I was wondering when these are actually applied to the document? And when it is determined if a certain rule in the root CSS stylesheets applies to a certain element? What spec should I look at for info like this?
